cluster.display: A __________ variable assigns a unique numerical value to each outcome of a random experiment.
A random variable assigns a unique numerical value to each __________ of a random experiment.
A random variable associates exactly __________ possible numerical outcome to each trial of a random experiment.
A __________ associates exactly one possible numerical outcome to each trial of a random experiment.
__________ random variables exist if possible values are a distinct list.
Discrete random variables exist if possible __________ are a distinct list.
__________ random variables can take any value within a certain interval.
Continuous random variables can take any value within a certain __________.
To distinguish between discrete and continuous random variables, we sometimes say that we __________ discrete variables and measure continuous variables.
To distinguish between discrete and continuous random variables, we sometimes say that we count discrete variables and __________ continuous variables.
To distinguish between discrete and continuous random variables, we sometimes say that we count discrete variables and measure __________ variables.
To distinguish between discrete and continuous random variables, we sometimes say that we count __________ variables and measure continuous variables.
To notate __________ random variables, we write P(X=x).
To notate discrete random variables, we write P(__________).
The probability __________ of a random variable is the list of all possible values and probabilities.
The probability distribution of a random variable is the list of all possible values and __________.
The probability distribution of a random variable must have probabilities between __________ and one.
The probability distribution of a random variable must have probabilities between zero and __________.
The __________ of a random variable must have probabilities between zero and one.
The probability distribution of a random variable must have probabilities that __________ to one.
The probability distribution of a random variable must have probabilities that sum to __________.
The probability distribution of a random variable must have __________ that sum to one.
The __________ of a random variable is notated as μ<sub>X</sub>.
The mean of a random variable is sometimes referred to as the __________ average.
The mean of a random variable is a weighted average that represents the __________ of its probability distribution.
The __________ of a random variable is a weighted average that represents the center of its probability distribution.
The mean of a random variable is a weighted average that represents the center of its __________.

Notated as σ2
X, the __________ of a random variable is the squared standard deviation.

Notated as σ2
X, the variance of a random variable is the __________ standard deviation.

Notated as σ2
X, the variance of a random variable is the squared __________.
When a variable has a larger standard deviation, we are __________ likely to find values farther away from the mean of that random variable.
When a variable has a __________ standard deviation, we are more likely to find values farther away from the mean of that random variable.
When a variable has a smaller __________, we are less likely to find values farther away from the mean of that random variable.
When a variable has a smaller standard deviation, we are less likely to find values farther away from the __________ of that random variable.
Values that fall within __________ standard deviations from the mean of a random variable are considered ordinary.
Values that fall within two __________ from the mean of a random variable are considered ordinary.
When combining random variables, we can sum the __________ and variances as long as the variables are independent of one another.
When combining random variables, we can sum the means and __________ as long as the variables are independent of one another.
When combining random variables, we can sum the means and variances as long as the variables are __________ of one another.
